Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Testing Alternative Hypotheses for the Goal of Orientation by Reef Fish Larvae throughout Development
Award.AbstractNarration:
A central question of animal behavior and population ecology research is, how far do fish offspring disperse from their parents? This is because the dispersal of fish larvae connects distinct marine populations, thereby influencing the size and genetic diversity of those populations. In previous studies, marine ecologists have used two approaches to understand population connectivity: genetic methods that measure connectivity; and, oceanographic models that predict connectivity. There is, however, a large gap between the measured and predicted patterns of connectivity, which may be caused by the behavior of the fish larvae. Indeed, many reef fish larvae are outstanding swimmers that have the potential to influence their dispersal, but do they know where they are going? The objective of this research is to study the orientation abilities of fish larvae in the wild, throughout development and under a variety of environmental conditions, to determine whether understanding behavior can bridge the gap between observations and predictions of population connectivity. The completion of this research will enable improved predictions of population connectivity for other species, which will aid in the development of effective networks of marine reserves. The project will include a mentorship program for undergraduates in aquaculture and research, outreach to K-12 girls through the Science Club for Girls internship program and collaboration with local high school teachers.

A significant gap in our understanding of marine ecology is the extent to which larval orientation behavior can influence the pattern of dispersal. This project will bridge this gap by investigating the ontogeny of larval orientation behavior using one tractable system: the neon goby, Elacatinus lori. The project has two main objectives: 1) to investigate changes in larval orientation abilities throughout development; and, 2) to test alternative hypotheses for the goal of larval orientation behavior, i.e., to determine what larvae are orienting toward. By deploying lab-reared larvae in a drifting in situ chamber, the researchers will test for an effect of age on the development of non-random orientation behavior, the proportion of larvae orienting and the precision of their orientation. The researchers will also manipulate the location of larval deployments to test and discriminate between alternative hypotheses for the goal of larval orientation. Ultimately, understanding the behavioral mechanisms of larval dispersal will increase our understanding of the causes of population connectivity and aid in the design of effective networks of marine reserves. Data will be archived at the National Oceanographic Data Center (NODC) or the NSF funded Knowledge Network for Biocomplexity (KNB).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

A central question of marine animal behavior and population ecology research is, to what extent does the behavior of larvae cause variation in patterns of dispersal and population connectivity? Many marine organisms begin life as larvae that develop in the pelagic environment before returning to reef habitat. These tiny larvae were once considered passive particles, at the whim of ocean currents. However, it is now recognized that late stage larvae have well-developed sensory and motor abilities that they might use to influence their dispersal. Yet, little is known about when orientation behaviors develop, how they change throughout ontogeny, and whether larvae are capable of goal-oriented movement that could influence patterns of larval dispersal. The overall objective of the proposed research was to investigate the ontogeny of larval orientation behavior using one tractable system: the neon goby, Elacatinus lori. There were three motives for this choice of study system: i) an empirical measurement of the dispersal kernel for this species indicated that larvae were nearly an order of magnitude less dispersed than would be expected based on a purely physical model, suggesting that orientation behavior may limit their dispersal; ii) E. lori larvae can be reared through the larval stage, which provided a reliable source of larvae of all ages for the proposed experiments; and iii) the Drifting In Situ Chamber (DISC), a proven behavioral observation platform, would allow measurement of larval orientation behavior in the ocean. The proposed research aimed to investigate changes in larval orientation abilities throughout development, and it was completed successfully.

 

Intellectual Merit

Generally, the proposal was motivated by an evolutionary model, which suggested that larvae that begin orienting early in development would have a higher probability of survival. More specifically, the proposal was motivated by the identification of a gap between observations of dispersal measured using direct genetic techniques and predictions of dispersal generated by biophysical models in this species. The latter result suggested that something - most likely larval behavior – must be causing a difference between the predictions of biophysical model and observations made using direct genetic methods. The proposed research aimed to determine whether reef fish larvae were able to orient early in development and determine the extent to which larvae might influence patterns of dispersal. As such, the research would be a novel test of the ontogeny of larval orientation abilities, and determine whether larvae are capable of goal-oriented movement that could influence patterns of marine population connectivity. We were able to complete the research as planned and the data are now being analyzed. The results will be published in a peer reviewed scientific journal and disseminated to the public in 2017.

 

Broader Impacts

The proposed research had three Broader Impact goals: 1) Integration of research and teaching; 2) Broadening participation of underrepresented groups; and 3) Broadening dissemination to enhance public understanding. In terms of the first goal, we provided three undergraduate students with training in animal behavior, marine ecology, aquaculture and scientific diving. All three students have gone on to study toward advanced degrees. In terms of the second goal, we provided an internship to one high school female from an under-represented group, in collaboration with Science Club For Girls. The student was mentored in all aspects of the scientific process, from formulating hypotheses to presenting results; the student has gone on to college in a STEM field. Finally, regarding the third goal, we gave a number of talks to students, teachers, and members of the general public who came through the research station where we were conducting our research. In this way, we were able to communicate our findings and the importance of our research to hundreds of people that we could not have reached otherwise.
